tn.text: Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: When all these things have come on you
tn.text: Here "these things" refer to the blessings and curses described in chapters 28-29. The phrase "have come on you" is an idiom that means to happen. AT: "When all these things happen to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: that I have set before you
tn.text: This speaks of the blessings and curses that Moses told the people as if they were objects that he set in front of them. AT: "that I have just now told you about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is an idiom. AT: "remember them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"while you are living in the other nations"
"has forced you to go"
Here "voice" is referring to what Yahweh says. AT: "obey what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: with all your heart and with all your soul
tn.text: The idiom "with all ... heart" means "completely" and "with all ... soul" means "with all your being." These two phrases have similar meaning. AT: "with all your being" or "with all your energy." Translate these words as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:29|4:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
"free you from your captivity." The abstract noun "captivity" can be translated as a clause. AT: "free you from those who had captured you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: If any of your exiled people are in the farthest places
tn.text: "Even those of your exiled people who are in the farthest places"
"under the sky" or "on the earth"
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
This is not a literal removal of flesh. It means God will remove their sin and enable them to love and obey him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: with all your heart and with all your soul
tn.text: The idiom "with all ... heart" means "completely" and "with all ... soul" means "with all your being." These two phrases have similar meaning. AT: "with all your being" or "with all your energy." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:29|4:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Here "voice" means what Yahweh says. AT: "obey what Yahweh says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will put all these curses on your enemies
tn.text: Moses speaks of curses as though they were a load or a cover that someone could physically put on top of a person. AT: "will cause your enemies to suffer from these curses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "hand" refers to the whole person. AT: "in all the work you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: in the fruit of your body ... in the fruit of your cattle ... in the fruit of your ground
tn.text: These three phrases are idioms for "in children ... in calves ... in crops." Similar words appear in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:28:03|28:4]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that I have written" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: with all your heart and all your soul
tn.text: The idiom "with all ... heart" means "completely" and "with all ... soul" means "with all your being." These two phrases have similar meaning. AT: "with all your being" or "with all your energy." Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:29|4:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: neither is it too far for you to reach
tn.text: Moses speaks of being able to understand what a commandment requires a person to do as if it were that person being able to reach a physical object. AT: "neither is it too difficult for you to understand what Yahweh requires you to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Who will go up for us to heaven and bring it down to us and make us able to hear it, so that we may do it?
tn.text: Here Moses uses a rhetorical question to emphasize that the people of Israel think that Yahweh's commands are too difficult for them to know. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Someone must travel to heaven to learn God's commands and then return to tell us what they are so we can obey them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: Who will go over the sea for us and bring it to us and make us to hear it, so that we may do it?
tn.text: This rhetorical question continues the idea that the people of Israel think Yahweh's commands are too difficult to know. This question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Someone must travel across the sea to learn God's commands and then return and tell us what they are." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: in your mouth and your heart
tn.text: This means that the people already know God's commands and can tell them to others. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Putting something where another person can see it is a metaphor for telling someone about something. AT: "I have told you about" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: life and good, death and evil
tn.text: You can make clear the implicit information. AT: "what is good and will cause you to live, and what is evil and will cause you to die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"and have many descendants"
Moses continues to speak to the Israelites as if they were one man, so the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: if your heart turns away ... but instead are drawn away and bow down to other gods and worship them
tn.text: Here "heart" refers to the whole person. This can be stated in active form. AT: "if you stop being loyal to God ... and the people living in the land convince you to bow down and worship other gods" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: to you today that you ... you will not prolong your days
tn.text: Moses speaks to the Israelites as a group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Long days are a metaphor for a long life. AT: "be able to live a long time." Translate these words as they are in [[:en:bible:notes:deu:04:25|4:26]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Moses speaks to the Israelites as if they were one man, so except where noted the words "you" and "your" here are singular. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: I call heaven and earth to witness
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) Moses is calling on all those who live in heaven and earth to be witnesses to what he says, or 2) Moses is speaking to heaven and earth as if they are people, and he is calling them to be witnesses to what he says (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_apostrophe]])
"to be willing to say that you have done evil things"
Moses speaks to the Israelites as a group. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Here "voice" refers to what Yahweh says. AT: "obey what he says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"and to rely on him"

tn.ref: For he is your life and the length of your days
tn.text: "Your life" and "the length of your days" are metonyms for the one who can give life and length of days. You can combine the two phrases if you need to. AT: "Yahweh is the only one who can enable you to live a long life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The ellipsis can be filled in. AT: "swore that he would give to your ancestors" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
